abstract.p: Letter from Michael Meyers, New York Civil Rights Coalition, scores Joyce Purnick for making much of Schools Chancellor Harold O Levy's being Jewish white man (May 18 Metro Matters); says there was all-male, all-white finalist pool that scared off competition from better-qualified people of color and women

block.p: In ''A Selection No Longer Unthinkable'' (Metro Matters, May 18), Joyce Purnick makes much of Harold O. Levy's being ''a Jewish white man'' as if to herald a new era of ''merit'' for the post of schools chancellor. This thesis is condescending to former minority chancellors.

In ''A Selection No Longer Unthinkable'' (Metro Matters, May 18), Joyce Purnick makes much of Harold O. Levy's being ''a Jewish white man'' as if to herald a new era of ''merit'' for the post of schools chancellor. This thesis is condescending to former minority chancellors.

Although Mr. Levy lacked the necessary education credentials, he easily obtained a state waiver so that he could assume the post of interim chancellor. The Board of Education installed him without imposing a condition on his appointment that he not become a candidate for the permanent post. Once in the job, Mr. Levy had the inside track and was given an insider's preference.
Realism scared off competition from better-qualified people of color and women. How else to explain an all-male, all-white finalist pool -- a pool of one?
MICHAEL MEYERS Executive Director New York Civil Rights Coalition New York, May 22, 2000
